title: What would you like to be the first to discover? - Quora

response.answer_text: If I have to be first to discover something, it would be the cure to Alzheimer's.  (Image Credit: Science Photo library. The right side of the brain has damage to neurons caused by Alzheimer’s) Alzheimer’s is a fantastically complex disease, with the cause still a matter of scientific debate. More than likely there are many causes or factors in a person getting Alzheimer’s. Principally the cause is probably genetic. In late-onset Alzheimer’s there has been a reasonable link made to the APOEe4 (apolipoprotein E (APOE)) gene[1]. It comes in different alleles, and I’m not going to get into that here. Beyond that, lifestyle and health choices throughout life can have an impact. Viruses and now even bacteria[2] could affect the development of Alzheimer’s. There is research that epigenetic factors, from everything mentioned and environment, could be a major factor[3]. I could go on, but this isn’t a technical answer. There are two types: late-onset, with symptoms appearing in a suffer’s 60’s and early-onset with symptoms appearing in a sufferer between the ages of 30–60 years old. Early onset is much rarer. Finding a cure has been horribly difficult, with a 99% failure rate. It’s also fantastically expensive, costing more than $10 million for just a Phase I trial. That’s before even more in-depth Phase III trials that compare to existing Alzheimer’s therapy. This cost, coupled with the failure rate, has discouraged many of the large pharmaceutical/biopharmaceutical companies from continuing to pursue a cure. Research continues, but it’s not a focus for many. The NIH spends more than $2.5 billion annually in Alzheimer’s research[4]. There has been a foundation built by Bill Gates and Dr. Howard Fillit, the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation, that is built around discovering early medicines and funding scientist led research. Although Alzheimer’s could be a larger area of giving, even spare-change (the spare-change model) because it is a disease that in one way or another, affects us all. That’s because this is a massively expensive disease as well as being widespread, with care costs exceeding $290 billion annually for all types of dementia (including Alzheimer’s). It could be $1.1 trillion by 2050, and between now and then, cumulatively it will cost $20.2 trillion to treat dementia, including Alzheimer’s. (see my #4 reference for information). So a cure for Alzheimer’s would have an obvious financial and economic benefit, and would more than likely make me fantastically wealthy. Not to mention the recipient of just about every major medical aware in the world, starting with the Nobel Prize in Medicine and working its way down. Which generates a comparatively modest amount of prize money. It has been estimated that a cure for Alzheimer’s could be worth upwards of $20 billion[5], and that was in 2016. As costs continue to rise, so does the potential revenue. Now it could be worth $30 billion, by 2050, $100 billion. Beyond the cost, which is daunting, you have the personal reality of Alzheimer’s. The fact that this is one of the most dehumanizing diseases in the world. It literally steals your mind, your thoughts, and most precious memories. Alzheimer’s changes your personality, turns you into a different person, a person that is frequently unpleasant and mean. It’s is not the Alzheimer’s sufferer who intends to be mean, or suspicious, or even violent, it is the way the disease affects the brain to cause damage to what directs behavior. When our minds are affected, that is the essence of what we are as individuals, we are no longer the individual we were. Other diseases can do this, no doubt, but not in quite the insidious way that Alzheimer’s does. The way it steals a person’s memory in reasons appears to be almost evil. It is heartbreaking for the family and friends involved, to see a loved one go through this, to no longer be the person you love. My grandmother (on my mother’s side) suffered from Alzheimer’s. It was very late onset, not coming on until her mid-80’s. But what it did to her was brutal to go through, and because of her advanced age, it progressed quickly. I’ve been personally affected by this disease because of my grandmother, and I suspect that many readers have as well. If I was the one somehow to find a miraculous cure to Alzheimer’s I would see an income of more than $2 billion per year, after cost, if not more. It would make me quite wealthy, without a doubt. Although that’s not the point, not at all. I would be able to save so much pain, pain from the sufferers, pain from their families, pain to the economy. I would be making a real impact on the human race for the better. That would be the real value in being first to finding a cure. But still, there would be wealth, what to do with that wealth? Several billion dollars a year would be enough to fund a powerful venture philanthropy group, if not my full medical research center. The cure for Alzheimer’s in my hands would build the most well-funded medical venture philanthropy foundation in the world.  (Actually the University of Minnesota’s Cancer and Cardiovascular research building) The Goldlight Group would fund promising new areas of medical research, especially in scientist led companies and non-profits. Using the income from an Alzheimer’s cure to fund other areas of research in neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson’s, MS and ALS, other genetic diseases, emerging and pandemic causing disease (like Ebola and other hemorrhagic diseases), antibiotic research, and cancer diagnostics and therapies. It would be my hope that a few investments and our profile of work would allow us to operate in total solvency within a reasonable amount of time. My personal enrichment would very much take a backseat to this, getting even richer on the back of disease isn’t something I find palpable. So while I would live well, a good percentage of it would be poured into philanthropy. That’s why I would like to be the one that discovers a cure, and what I would do if I did. Credit goes to Elke Weiss for me finding this question, and how thought-provoking it is. Thanks, Elke. Her answer is a bit more ambitious than my own, and far lighter in tone. Footnotes[1] What Causes Alzheimer's Disease?[2] We may finally know what causes Alzheimer’s – and how to stop it[3] Epigenetics in Alzheimer's disease: a focus on DNA modifications.[4] http://act.alz.org/site/DocServer/2015_Appropriations_Fact_Sheet__FY16_.pdf?docID=3641[5] This Alzheimer's drug could be worth $20 billion

Teleportation! Wouldn’t that be cool? And hopefully of a type not limited by the speed of light. You know, folding space or some kind of other-dimensional transport. I’d like to have a portal to the North Pole that I could use as a refrigerator, or be able to visit my mom or brother who live hours away by simply walking across the room. It’s just the first thing that popped into my head, but yeah - I’ve always thought teleportation would be awesome.

Cold fusion technology, which would be cheap to create, clean to use, and provide enormous energy without waste. Essentially, Cold fusion means it is economically-viable to recycle all waste, restore wilderness and waterways to pristine conditions, and keep a planetary biosphere from extinction. What is Cold Fusion? I imagine that it would make me a multi-billionaire of the Jeff Bezos variety, I’d basically be one of the richest people in humanity. I’d also win a million awards, like the Nobel Prize in Physics, the Dan David Prize:, the Heineken Prize:, The Japan Prize, Wolf Foundation Prize:, Albert Einstein World Award of Science: and the Copley Medal. Plus, like Amy Farah Fowler, I’d totally wear a tiara and ask for a royal title. I figure for saving the world, I could get a letters patent to become Her Grace, the Duchess of Cumberland (extinct royal dukedom) so people could curtsy to me.  The Meaning Behind Meghan Markle's Wedding Tiara: How It Pays Tribute to Her New Royal Family And I’d insist on everyone in Krav Maga to address me as such. “Hi Elke.” “Your grace.” “You don’t have to call me that.” “You need to call me that.” “No.” Save the world, and I’d still not get respect.

A star. I’d love to be the first one to find some random star. Maybe even a planet. I love astronomy and have ever since I was a kid. Space was where I spent most of my time reading as a child and I’d imagine (to whatever extent I could manage) that I’d grow up and be a famous astronomer some day. I’d imagine being the first one to discover something that nobody else had seen before. Now though? I’d still love to get a star or planet.

Thanks James for a2a. I would like the question to be modified as “you wanted to be the first person to discover something. What is it?” When I was studying, I was deeply thinking about how we could have communication with a paralyzed person through head gears and necessary equipment in between. I had based my thinking on the principle of real-time modulation of audio signals on telephone sets that we are able to send and receive. I examined many modes and working of transducers needed. Obviously it was not easy. Underlying signal processing (in time domain and frequency domain) mainly remained a hypothetical issue and conjectural models would not help. I AM SURE ONE DAY THAT WILL BE ACHIEVED. At least someone can say that I was one of the persons who ever thought about that and tried but fell too short. Thanks for reading my input here.

A cure for Multiple Sclerosis. Indirectly, MS killed my mother (she couldn’t fight pneumonia because too many muscles were too weak to help her breathe enough), and I’ve been steadily more disabled by it myself since my own MS diagnosis 25 years ago. My most recent GF (and the love of my life since I was 13 years old) is an emerita molecular biologist with ongoing cell-signaling research in pediatric cancers and MS. Perhaps something she figures out will truly help others to *find* such a cure, but… … even with the world’s best minds on the job, I’d still be very surprised if any “cure” shows up before I die: I’m 60 years old…and though it’s possible and I’ll try… I don’t see myself living to 80, and I suspect that a “cure” (or treatment effective enough to be equated to one) is a lot more than 50 years in the future.

In order to not repeat some of the other fine suggestions… A technological means by which gravity could be created or manipulated. Artificial gravity, more or less. The applications are seemingly endless.
How to teleport. Jumper (2008) The Stars My Destination - Wikipedia

I have a hypothesis, Theory, supposition, that I would like to be correct about. It's about Dark Matter And The Expansion Of Our Universe. I have a YouTube video on my Quora profile that. I made in 2013. Basically it speaks that dark matter and dark energy is the byproduct of the mass that falls into black holes, and that particle accelerators such as CERN are reverse-engineered black holes. That black holes are the natural processes of the universe that recycles and creates Mass. Whereas particle accelerators break the mass down into its Elemental particles in all of its flavors and types but cannot store them as black holes do. Here is the link to the profile page. Gaynor Lowell
I don’t care about that. At all. If something needs to be discovered it will be. Doesn’t matter who does it. We’re all in this together.
A way to make people … all people … get along with each other. :)

How many wild-types are there? (Not where they are as I do not care.)What power do they have and what distinction do they have? Do they have all? To what extent?What is the nature of their life?How does the interaction between the rule and the exceptions interact?How high is 2.9 to 4.6 on the hypercycle? Are there exceptions there?What psychodynamics counteract the status quo?
A 50 pound gold nugget under a rock
Talking animals. What a delight it would be to have absolute communication with the companion who shares your life!
Concluding posit to unified field theory.
CURE FOR .A L L . DISEASE AND ILLNESSES CANCER, HEART DISEASE, HEART FAILURE, STROKE, ALZHEIMER’S, SCHIZOPHREINA, PARANOIA, DEPRESSION A N D . A U T I S M !!!
concrete, irrefutable evidence of a formerly living, multi-cellular, indigenous organism on Mars (probably microbial).
I want to be the person who finds out how to end poverty.
The solution to the P versus NP problem would be extremely cool to have found, I guess.
A cure for all types of cancer~!
Sentient alien life. Or How to cheaply transform sandstone into gold.
